update.description:
The following header files are included in the gazebo repository:
~~~
gazebo/common/Common.hh
gazebo/physics/Physics.hh
gazebo/rendering/Rendering.hh
gazebo/sensors/Sensors.hh
gazebo/transport/Transport.hh
~~~
and the following headers are auto-generated:

~~~
gazebo/common/common.hh
gazebo/physics/physics.hh
gazebo/rendering/rendering.hh
gazebo/sensors/sensors.hh
gazebo/transport/transport.hh
~~~
This will prevent successful installation on filesystems that aren't case-sensitive (such as the default filesystem for Mac OS X).

This pull request renames the header files by adding `Iface` (ie. `Physics.hh` => `PhysicsIface.hh`). It also changes the header guards in those files and the include statements in the rest of the repository.

This pull request will break any external packages that currently include these header files. A workaround is to always include the all-inclusive lowercase headers (ie. `physics.hh`). As such, this is targeted to default, intended for gazebo 2.0.
update.title: Fix #775: support for case-insensitive filesystems
update.reason: I broke the mac build in 8d3e115. I'm going to fix it and resubmit.

content.raw: I was just testing this on the Mac side, and the fix in 8d3e115 broke the mac build. I'm going to decline this and resubmit once it's fixed.
content.html: I was just testing this on the Mac side, and the fix in 8d3e115 broke the mac build. I'm going to decline this and resubmit once it's fixed.

content.raw:
Once this gets merged, getting the default branch to build on Mac OS X will be one modest pull request away:

#!/osrf/gazebo/compare/osx..issue_775#diff

Once this gets merged, getting the default branch to build on Mac OS X will be one modest pull request away:

#!/osrf/gazebo/compare/osx..issue_775#diff

content.raw: I added the _GAZEBO_ prefix because other applications my use things like "SENSOR", or "CAMERA"
content.html: I added the GAZEBO prefix because other applications my use things like "SENSOR", or "CAMERA"

content.raw: This brings up a broader question about uniqueness of header guards. `Sensors.hh` previously used `_GAZEBO_SENSORS_HH_`, so I adapted that, though I didn't add the `_GAZEBO_` prefix to others if they didn't already have it. @nkoenig Any thoughts?
content.html: This brings up a broader question about uniqueness of header guards. Sensors.hh previously used _GAZEBO_SENSORS_HH_, so I adapted that, though I didn't add the _GAZEBO_ prefix to others if they didn't already have it. @nkoenig Any thoughts?

content.raw: Good call, I forgot that one.

content.raw: Can you add message to all these if blocks that spits out a big warning message when the version is 2.0.0? That way we won't forget to remove these if blocks when the version hits 2.0.
content.html: Can you add message to all these if blocks that spits out a big warning message when the version is 2.0.0? That way we won't forget to remove these if blocks when the version hits 2.0.

content.raw: I just discussed this with John, and he suggested leaving header files with the old name in place with a deprecation warning for an extra release cycle. With some cmake magic to detect case-insensitive filesystems, we could only install the old-style header on case-sensitive filesystems. I'm going to look into this.
content.html: I just discussed this with John, and he suggested leaving header files with the old name in place with a deprecation warning for an extra release cycle. With some cmake magic to detect case-insensitive filesystems, we could only install the old-style header on case-sensitive filesystems. I'm going to look into this.
